_header: Each man followeth his own fantasy
Note:

_description: John Lydgate, ‘Amor et Pecunia’ — seventeen 8-line stanzas

BodAsh59.First Lines:
EChe man to folowe his owen fantasyeLyche as it falleþe in
                    fallþe in his opyniounHis witte enclyninge on to þat
                    partyeWhere as his herte haþe made elleccyoun…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…Suche love graunted in trouþe and stabulnesseShal haue
                    his guerdoun and hys mede
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Nowe foloweþe here nexst a questyoun made in wyse of balade by
                    þat Philosofre Lidegate daun Johan. Wheþer is moste preferred in
                    þe worlde þat nowe is / Amor vincit omnia. or Mentiris quod
                        pecunia (f. 41)

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
Eche man folowith his owne fantasielyke as It fallythe in his
                    oppinion…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…soche love groundyd in trouthe and stabellnesseshall have of
                    god his reward and mede
BLAdd29729.Note:
Rubric after last line: ‘deo gracias / Iohn lydgat /
                    wryttyn by Iohn Stowe’ (f. 126).
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
Amor vincit omnia / mentoris uod pecunia / Iohn lydgate(rubric
                    heading, f. 124v; by scribe, John Stow)

BLHar2251.First Lines:
Eche man folwith his owne fantasyeLiche as it fallith in his
                    oppinioun…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Such love grounded in love and stablenesseShal have of god
                    his gwerdoun and his mede
